The point for [fraction numerator=5 denominator=7]five sevenths[/fraction] is farther to the right than the point for [fraction numerator=3 denominator=7]three sevenths[/fraction]. When fractions have the same [vocab]denominator[/vocab], we order them by looking at their numerators. The smallest [vocab]numerator[/vocab] is 1, so [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] is the least. The next [vocab]numerator[/vocab] is 3, so [fraction numerator=3 denominator=6]three sixths[/fraction] comes next. The largest [vocab]numerator[/vocab] is 5, so [fraction numerator=5 denominator=6]five sixths[/fraction] is the greatest. That gives us the order: [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction], [fraction numerator=3 denominator=6]three sixths[/fraction], [fraction numerator=5 denominator=6]five sixths[/fraction]. That's how we order fractions with the same [vocab]denominator[/vocab] - we compare the numerators from smallest to largest.

Let me walk you through this. When we compare [fraction numerator=5 denominator=8]five eighths[/fraction] and [fraction numerator=2 denominator=8]two eighths[/fraction], notice that both fractions have the same [vocab]denominator[/vocab] - 8. That means both fractions are divided into [vocab]eighths[/vocab], which are the same size pieces. Since the pieces are the same size, we just need to compare how many pieces each fraction has. [fraction numerator=5 denominator=8]five eighths[/fraction] has 5 pieces and [fraction numerator=2 denominator=8]two eighths[/fraction] has 2 pieces. Since 5 is greater than 2, we have more pieces in [fraction numerator=5 denominator=8]five eighths[/fraction], making it the greater fraction. The correct explanation is: Both fractions show [vocab]eighths[/vocab]. 5 > 2, so [fraction numerator=5 denominator=8]five eighths[/fraction] is greater.
